oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from P.J. Williamson to his wife, Eunice, during the Civil War, 1865 May 16
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A letter from Dutch immigrant, Peter J. Williamson, back home to his wife, Eunice, during the Civil War. In 1862 Williamson enlisted as a Private in the 1st Wisconsin Cavalry, Company F and was ultimately promoted to Full 1st Lieutenant. During the war, Williamson's regiment was involved in scouting and raids in Missouri and Arkansas and saw battle in the Middle Tennessee, Chickamauga, and Atlanta campaigns. In this letter from Nashville, Tennessee, Williamson has received Eunice's letter from the 7th. He relates to her a message he sent concerning a debt they owe and he expresses optimism about finding them a house in Nashville soon and at a reasonable price. He tells her that he and a partner have agreed to open an architectural office and predicts to do well in time given there are no other architects in Nashville at the time. He reports that Captain Seaton is probably going to Georgia and Mrs. Seaton back north. Williamson mentions that Jefferson Davis' train is scheduled to be traveling through Nashville that night on its way to Washington although he will not be leaving his car due to fears of assassination. He closes by speaking of friends and family including a request to help find a former soldier with the 21st Wisconsin Infantry Regiment. Forms part of the Peter J. Williamson Letters. 1 letter : col. ; 8 x 10 in.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Williamson, Peter J., 1823-1907; Williamson, Eunice Leihy, 1840-1928; Davis, Jefferson, 1808-1889--Captivity, 1865-1867; Seaton, Algernon S.
